title: Frances Ginsberg
text:
Frances Ginsberg (March 11, 1955 – December 24, 2010) was an American <a href="opera">opera</a> singer. "<a href="Opera%20News">Opera News</a>" magazine described her as "a <a href="Spinto%20soprano">lirico-spinto soprano</a> of striking temperament whose vivid style made her an audience favorite at <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a> and other U.S. companies in the 1980s and 1990s."
Life and career.
Ginsberg was born to Jewish parents in <a href="St.%20Louis%2C%20Missouri">St. Louis, Missouri</a> in 1955.
In 1973, she graduated from <a href="Ladue%20Horton%20Watkins%20High%20School">Ladue Horton Watkins High School</a> in <a href="Ladue%2C%20Missouri">Ladue, Missouri</a>, and in 1979 she graduated from the <a href="University%20of%20Kansas">University of Kansas</a> with fine arts degrees in theatre and voice. She then pursued further studies at the <a href="Lyric%20Opera%20of%20Chicago">Lyric Opera of Chicago</a>'s <a href="Center%20for%20American%20Artists">Center for American Artists</a>. She later studied opera privately with <a href="Carlo%20Bergonzi%20%28tenor%29">Carlo Bergonzi</a>, <a href="Renata%20Tebaldi">Renata Tebaldi</a> and <a href="Eve%20Queler">Eve Queler</a>. She also studied with conductor Marco Munari of <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala</a>, while living in Milan.
Still a college student, she made her professional opera debut in 1977 at the <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Opera">Santa Fe Opera</a> as the milliner in the United States premiere of <a href="Nino%20Rota">Nino Rota</a>'s "<a href="Il%20cappello%20di%20paglia%20di%20Firenze">The Italian Straw Hat</a>". Her first major success came in 1986 when she made her debut at the <a href="New%20York%20City%20Opera">New York City Opera</a> (NYCO) in the dual roles of Margherita and Elena in <a href="Arrigo%20Boito">Arrigo Boito</a>'s "<a href="Mefistofele">Mefistofele</a>". She subsequently appeared with the NYCO as Donna Elvira in <a href="Wolfgang%20Amadeus%20Mozart">Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart</a>'s "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>", Mimì in <a href="Giacomo%20Puccini">Giacomo Puccini</a>'s "<a href="La%20boh%C3%A8me">La bohème</a>", and Violetta in <a href="Giuseppe%20Verdi">Giuseppe Verdi</a>'s "<a href="La%20traviata">La traviata</a>". In 1990 she made her debut at the <a href="Metropolitan%20Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a> as Rosalinde in <a href="Johann%20Strauss%20II">Johann Strauss II</a>'s "<a href="Die%20Fledermaus">Die Fledermaus</a>".
Other US companies Ginsberg performed with during her career were <a href="Cincinnati%20Opera">Cincinnati Opera</a>, <a href="Fort%20Worth%20Opera">Fort Worth Opera</a>, <a href="Houston%20Grand%20Opera">Houston Grand Opera</a>, <a href="Pittsburgh%20Opera">Pittsburgh Opera</a>, <a href="San%20Diego%20Opera">San Diego Opera</a>, <a href="Santa%20Fe%20Opera">Santa Fe Opera</a>, <a href="Utah%20Opera">Utah Opera</a>, and the <a href="Washington%20National%20Opera">Washington National Opera</a>. On the international stage she made appearances with, among others, the <a href="Op%C3%A9ra%20de%20Nice">Opéra de Nice</a>, the <a href="Op%C3%A9ra%20Royal%20de%20Wallonie">Opéra Royal de Wallonie</a>, the <a href="Scottish%20Opera">Scottish Opera</a> and the <a href="Welsh%20National%20Opera">Welsh National Opera</a>. Some of the other roles she performed on stage were Abigaille in "<a href="Nabucco">Nabucco</a>", Amelia in "<a href="Un%20ballo%20in%20maschera">Un ballo in maschera</a>", Cio-Cio-San in "<a href="Madama%20Butterfly">Madama Butterfly</a>", Desdemona in "<a href="Otello">Otello</a>", Donna Anna in "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>", Elvira in "<a href="Ernani">Ernani</a>", Lady Macbeth in "<a href="Macbeth%20%28opera%29">Macbeth</a>", Leonora in "<a href="Il%20trovatore">Il trovatore</a>", Leonora in "<a href="La%20forza%20del%20destino">La forza del destino</a>", Magda in "<a href="La%20Rondine">La Rondine</a>", Nedda in "<a href="Pagliacci">Pagliacci</a>", and the title heroines in "<a href="Aida">Aida</a>", "<a href="Manon%20Lescaut">Manon Lescaut</a>", "<a href="Norma%20%28opera%29">Norma</a>" and "<a href="Tosca">Tosca</a>".
Death.
She abandoned her career in 2007 after being diagnosed with ovarian cancer. Ginsberg died in 2010 at age 55 in <a href="Riverdale%2C%20Bronx">The Bronx (Riverdale), New York</a> of ovarian cancer which had metastasized to her brain and spine.
